Ideal

Let $R$ be a ring. A subset $\mathfrak{a} \subset R$ is called an ideal in $R$ if: (i) $\mathfrak{a}$ is an additive subgroup of $R$. (ii) For any $r \in R$ and $a \in \mathfrak{a}$, it holds that $ra \in \mathfrak{a}$.
Trivial Ideals
In any ring $R$, the zero ideal $\{0\}$ and the unit ideal $R$ are called trivial ideals. These are the only ideals if $R$ is a field.
Sum of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the sum $\mathfrak{a}+\mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{a+b ; a \in \mathfrak{a}, b \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Product of Ideals

For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the product $\mathfrak{a} \cdot \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\left\{\sum_{i=1}^{<\infty} a_{i} b_{i} ; a_{i} \in \mathfrak{a}, b_{i} \in \mathfrak{b}\right\}$.
Intersection of Ideals
For ideals $\mathfrak{a}, \mathfrak{b}$ in a ring $R$, the intersection $\mathfrak{a} \cap \mathfrak{b}$ is defined as $\{x ; x \in \mathfrak{a} \text { and } x \in \mathfrak{b}\}$.
Principal Ideal
For an element $a \in R$, the principal ideal generated by $a$ is $R a:=\{r a ; r \in R\}$. It is the smallest ideal in $R$ containing $a$.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Finitely Generated Ideal
An ideal $\mathfrak{a}$ in a ring $R$ is finitely generated if it admits a finite system of generators.
Principal Ideal Domain
A ring $R$ is called a principal ideal domain if it is an integral domain and every ideal of $R$ is principal.
Ring Homomorphism

Let $R$ and $R'$ be rings. A map $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a ring homomorphism if it satisfies two conditions: (i) $\varphi(a+b)=\varphi(a)+\varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$, making $\varphi$ a group homomorphism with respect to addition, and (ii) $\varphi(a \cdot b)=\varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$ and $\varphi(1)=1$, making $\varphi$ a monoid homomorphism with respect to multiplication.
Ring Isomorphism

A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.
Ring Monomorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.
Ring Epimorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an epimorphism if it is surjective.
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: The definition of trivial ideals relies on the concept of an ideal, as trivial ideals are specific examples of ideals.
The definition of the sum of ideals requires the concept of an ideal, as it involves the sum of two ideals.
The definition of the product of ideals requires the concept of an ideal, as it involves the product of two ideals.
The definition of the intersection of ideals requires the concept of an ideal, as it involves the intersection of two ideals.
The definition of a principal ideal requires the concept of an ideal, as a principal ideal is a specific type of ideal generated by a single element.
The definition of a system of generators of an ideal requires the concept of an ideal, as it describes a way to generate an ideal using a family of elements.
The definition of a finitely generated ideal requires the concept of an ideal, as it describes an ideal that can be generated by a finite system of generators.
The definition of a principal ideal domain requires the concept of an ideal, as it describes a ring in which every ideal is principal.
The definition of a ring isomorphism relies on the concept of a ring homomorphism, as an isomorphism is a bijective homomorphism with an inverse.
The definition of a ring monomorphism relies on the concept of a ring homomorphism, as a monomorphism is an injective homomorphism.
The definition of a ring epimorphism relies on the concept of a ring homomorphism, as an epimorphism is a surjective homomorphism.
